Artist's Drive is a 9 mi/14 km one-way scenic drive off Badwater Road. The paved road, heading north towards Furnace Creek, winds through colourful volcanic and sedimentary hills. It is best seen in the afternoon as the setting sun enhances the colours. RV's and trailers are not allowed on the road. There are several pull-offs along the road, as well as a small parking lot at the main attraction - Artist's Palette.

It's the biggest mistake we made at Death Valley. We ended up having to skip Badwater Basin because of this. It was getting dark, and we had to drive home. If you do have enough time (e.g. an entire day at Death Valley), then you might as well see this. The colour green was about the only one that stood out.

A few general tips for Death Valley:
- Death Valley holds the record for the highest reliably recorded air temperature in the world (134°F / 56.7°C). Therefore, make sure you have lots of food and especially water. Wear breathable clothes.
- If your car doesn't have a GPS, use real maps or offline Google maps since you won't be able to connect to the internet. We used offline Google maps.
- Bring a nice camera so you get some unforgettable photos!

Artist's Drive is a paved side road, off of the Badwater Road in the center of Death Valley National Park. It is a one-way road that cuts off to the east, about ten miles south of Furnace Creek, and made five or so miles north of Badwater. The road then circles back to the north, to Badwater Road, The colors are amazing in places, and there are many interesting road cuts and rock formations. One thing we noticed was that while the April temperature at Badwater Basin was 97 degrees, we hit one small isolated valley on the Artist's Drive where it was a reliable 111 F degrees (44 C).
I'd love to go back. This is a great place to take photographs, but be warned, it's HOT and you need to take water with you (there are no services).
